sen.j: 『教学聖旨』（きょうがくせいし）は、1879年に明治天皇より参議伊藤博文・同寺島宗則（文部卿兼務）に出された教育方針。
sen.e: Kyogaku Seishi is an education policy presented to Sangi (Councilors) Hirobumi ITO and Munenori TERASHIMA (also the Mombukyo [chief of the Ministry of Education]) by the Meiji Emperor in 1879.
Kyogaku Seishi is an education policy presented to Sangi (Councilors) Hirobumi ITO and Munenori TERASHIMA (also the Mombukyo [chief of the Ministry of Education]) by the Meiji Emperor in 1879.
Kyogaku Seishi is an education policy presented to Sangi (Councilors) Hirobumi ITO and Munenori TERASHIMA (also the Mombukyo [chief of the Ministry of Education]) by the Meiji Emperor in 1879.

sen.j: 総論である「教学大旨」及び小学校教育に関する「小学条目二件」から構成されている。
sen.e: It consisted of two parts: one the overall outline 'Kyoiku Taishi' and two about primary school education 'Shogaku Jomoku Niken'.
It consisted of two parts: the overall outline 'Kyoiku Taishi' and about primary school education 'Shogaku Jomoku Niken'.
sen.cmt: 「two parts」先に出ているので、「;」後に「one…and two」と続ける必要はなく、「and」のみでよいと思います。
sen.e: It consisted of two parts: a section called 'Kyoiku Taishi', which provided an overall outline; and a section called 'Shogaku Jomoku Niken', which provided a description of primary school education.

sen.j: 学制以来の明治政府の啓蒙主義的な教育政策を否定し、明治以前の儒教中心の教育に戻すこと、庶民教育は読み書き算盤を主体とする実学と儒教的徳目育成のみで十分とする趣旨であった。
sen.e: Opposed to the thought-provoking education policy of the Meiji government since the Government Order of Education in Japan, the Seishi was to return the policy to the pro-Meiji education with Confucianism as its center and for the common people, practical learning with the main focus on reading, writing and arithmetic and teaching of Confucian types of virtue should be enough.

Opposed to the thought-provoking education policy of the Meiji government since the Government Order of Education in Japan, Kyogaku Seishi was to return the educational policy to the pro-Meiji education with Confucianism as its center, and considered that only practical learning with the main focus on reading, writing and arithmetic and teaching of Confucian types of virtue are sufficient for the common people.
sen.cmt: for common peopleとある場所の意味が、原文を読まないと分かりにくいので、「for the common people」を文末に移動し、「, and considered that only practical learning…」としました。また、should be enoughから are sufficientと変更しました。文中にthe seishiとありますが、ドキュメント中にある説明はkyogaku seishiのもので、seishiのみの説明は無いため、Kyogaku Seishiとします。またthe policyとある箇所は何の政策が分からないため、the educational policyとします。
sen.e: Opposed to the thought-provoking education policy of the Meiji government that had been in place since the Government Order of Education in Japan, Kyogaku Seishi wanted to return to the type of Confucian-centered educational system that had been pursued prior to the Meiji period; he believed that just practical learning with the main focus on reading, writing and arithmetic combined with the teaching of Confucian-type virtues was sufficient for the masses.

sen.j: ところがこの文章の実際の執筆者が保守的な儒学者として知られていた侍補の元田永孚であることが分かると、伊藤は激怒した。
sen.e: However, when Ito found out that the person who was to actually write the Shishi was Nagazane MOTODA, a Joho (Emperor's aide) well known as a conservative Confucianist, Ito was enraged.
However, Ito was enraged when he found out that the actual writer of the document was a jiho (Emperor's aide) Nagazane MOTODA who was well known as a conservative Confucianist.
sen.cmt: 分かりやすくするため、Ito was enragedを先に、when he…を後に続けました。the person who was to actually write を、簡潔に、「actual writer of」と変更しました。Nagazane MOTODA, a Joho (Emperor's aide) から、a Joho (Emperor's aide) Nagazane MOTODA who…としました。文中にthe seishiとありますが、ドキュメント中にある説明はkyogaku seishiのもので、seishiのみの説明は無く、また原文では「この文章」とあるので、（文章ではなく文書ととり、）the documentと訳します。侍補（じほ）をa Johoと訳していますが、jihoの誤訳です。
sen.e: However, Ito was enraged when he found out that the actual writer of the document was a jiho (Emperor's aide) Nagazane MOTODA who was well known as a conservative Confucianist.

sen.j: かねてより日本の近代化そのものに否定的な考えを持っていることで知られた元田に警戒感を抱いていた伊藤は、ただちに「教育議」を執筆して元田の主張こそ現実離れの空論であると噛み付き、両者は激しく論争した。
sen.e: Ito had developed a sense of caution for a long while against Motoda who was known for his negative attitude toward the modernization of Japan wrote the 'Kyoikugi' (Proposition on Education), Ito saw Motoda's thoughts as unrealistic ideology and they fiercely confronted each other.

For a long time, Ito had been wary of Motoda who was known for his adverse opinion towards the modernization of Japan, and Ito immediately wrote 'Kyoikugi' (Proposition on Education) protesting vehemently that Motoda's view is the unrealistic theory; and thus they fiercely confronted each other.
sen.cmt: 訳文が分かりにくいので、書き換えました。
sen.e: For a long time, Ito had been wary of Motoda who was known for his adverse opinion towards the modernization of Japan, and Ito immediately wrote 'Kyoikugi' (Proposition on Education) protesting vehemently that Motoda's view is the unrealistic theory; and thus they fiercely confronted each other.

sen.j: まもなく伊藤は侍補の廃止を決断する一方、高まる自由民権運動に対抗するために道徳教育の強化には同意して政府の教育政策の継続が認められた。
sen.e: Soon Ito decided to abolish the role of Joho but agreed to strengthen moral education to hold out against the Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right) and decided to allow the continuation of the government's education policy.

Soon Ito decided to abolish the role of jiho but agreed to strengthen moral education to hold out against the Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right) and decided to allow the continuation of the government's education policy.
sen.cmt: 侍補（じほ）をJohoと訳していますが、jihoの誤訳です。
sen.e: Soon Ito decided to abolish the role of jiho but agreed to strengthen moral education to hold out against the Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right) and decided to allow the continuation of the government's education policy.

sen.j: だが、明治政府の立憲国家建設に真っ向から反対して天皇親政を唱える元田に対する明治天皇の信任は増すばかりであり、伊藤らは政府の方針と天皇の意向の乖離に苦慮することになる。
sen.e: However, with the deepening of the Meiji Emperor's trust for Motoda who was directly opposed to the Meiji government's plan to establish a constitutional state, Ito and others were to struggle with the dissociation between the government's policy and the Emperor's wish.

However, with the deepening of the Meiji Emperor's trust for Motoda who insisted on direct rule by the Emperor and raised frontal objection to the Meiji government's plan to establish a constitutional state, Ito struggled with the dissociation between the government's policy and the Emperor's intention.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ：「天皇親政を唱える」directly opposed to >> raised frontal objection to「伊藤ら」をIto and othersしていますが、and othersは必要ないかと思います（ドキュメント内で「誰」とは言われていないので）。were to struggle >> struggled「天皇の意向」をEmperor's wish としていますが、「望み、願い」というニュアンスより、intentionの「意図、意志」という方が正しいかと思います。
sen.e: However, with the deepening of the Meiji Emperor's trust for Motoda who insisted on direct rule by the Emperor and raised frontal objection to the Meiji government's plan to establish a constitutional state, Ito struggled with the dissociation between the government's policy and the Emperor's intention.

sen.j: 一方、元田の理念はそのままの形では実現されなかったものの、その儒教的・絶対的な天皇中心主義は『教育勅語』という形で実現することになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, Motoda's idea was not realized in its original form but his Confucian and absolute Imperialism was realized in the form of the "Kyoiku Chokugo" (Imperial Rescript on Education).
